rows: Detects blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signal changes; increased neural activity = increased local blood flow = increased oxygenated hemoglobin
Research on cognitive processes, presurgical functional mapping, language lateralization
Radioactive tracer (e.g., FDG labeled with fluorine-18) injected; emits positrons that produce gamma rays detected by scanner
Radioactive tracer emitting gamma rays directly; single-photon detection
Cerebral blood flow patterns, epileptic focus localization (ictal SPECT), differentiating dementia subtypes
questions.correct_value: Detecting hypometabolism in Alzheimer's (temporoparietal), dopamine system imaging (Parkinson's), amyloid plaque imaging
options: Cerebral blood flow patterns, epileptic focus localization (ictal SPECT), differentiating dementia subtypes
Detecting hypometabolism in Alzheimer's (temporoparietal), dopamine system imaging (Parkinson's), amyloid plaque imaging
Research on cognitive processes, presurgical functional mapping, language lateralization
Structural volumetric analysis, white matter tract mapping, cortical thickness measurement
questions.explanation: PET imaging uses radioactive tracers such as FDG to measure metabolic activity, making it uniquely suited for detecting hypometabolism in Alzheimer's disease (particularly in temporoparietal regions), imaging the dopamine system in Parkinson's disease, and visualizing amyloid plaques. SPECT is used for cerebral blood flow and ictal epilepsy localization, while fMRI is primarily a research tool for cognitive processes and presurgical mapping.

rows: Stimulus → Body response → Emotion (we feel afraid because we run)
Physiological arousal and emotional experience occur simultaneously
Emotion requires both physiological arousal AND cognitive labeling of that arousal
Cognitive appraisal MUST precede emotional experience; appraisal determines the emotion
Stimulus → Cognitive appraisal → Emotion + body response
questions.correct_value: Stimulus → Thalamus → Simultaneous body response + subjective emotion
options: Stimulus → Body response → Emotion (we feel afraid because we run)
Stimulus → Thalamus → Simultaneous body response + subjective emotion
Stimulus → Cognitive appraisal → Emotion + body response
questions.explanation: The Cannon-Bard theory proposes that the thalamus simultaneously sends signals to the cortex (producing subjective emotion) and to the body (producing physiological arousal), meaning both occur at the same time rather than sequentially. This contrasts with the James-Lange theory (body response precedes emotion), Schachter-Singer (arousal requires cognitive labeling), and Lazarus (cognitive appraisal must come first).

rows: Maintains verbal and acoustic information through rehearsal
Maintains and manipulates visual images and spatial information
Limited capacity for visual objects and spatial locations
Attentional control system; coordinates subsystems, shifts focus, inhibits responses
Limited attentional resources; most related to prefrontal cortex function
Integrates information across subsystems and links to long-term memory
Added by Baddeley (2000); multimodal, limited capacity (~4 chunks)
questions.correct_value: ~2 seconds of speech; word-length effect; phonological similarity effect
options: Limited capacity for visual objects and spatial locations
~2 seconds of speech; word-length effect; phonological similarity effect
Added by Baddeley (2000); multimodal, limited capacity (~4 chunks)
Limited attentional resources; most related to prefrontal cortex function
questions.explanation: The phonological loop maintains verbal and acoustic information through subvocal rehearsal, with a capacity of approximately 2 seconds of speech. It is characterized by the word-length effect (longer words are harder to maintain) and the phonological similarity effect (similar-sounding items are more easily confused), distinguishing it from the visuospatial sketchpad, central executive, and episodic buffer.

rows: Alzheimer's (ACh deficit); myasthenia gravis (receptor antibodies); botulinum toxin (blocks release)
Reward, motivation, motor control, executive function
Parkinson's (DA deficit); schizophrenia (DA excess in mesolimbic pathway); addiction (mesolimbic pathway)
Mood regulation, sleep, appetite, impulse control
Depression (5-HT deficit hypothesis); OCD; anxiety disorders; SSRIs increase 5-HT availability
Depression; PTSD (NE hyperactivity); ADHD (NE/DA deficit); SNRIs target NE + 5-HT
Primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain
Anxiety (GABA deficit); benzodiazepines enhance GABA; alcohol potentiates GABA; seizures (GABA deficit)
Primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain; learning (LTP)
Runner's high; naloxone reverses opioid overdose by blocking endorphin/opioid receptors
questions.correct_value: Excitotoxicity (excessive glutamate causes neuronal death); involved in stroke damage; NMDA receptors in LTP
options: Anxiety (GABA deficit); benzodiazepines enhance GABA; alcohol potentiates GABA; seizures (GABA deficit)
Excitotoxicity (excessive glutamate causes neuronal death); involved in stroke damage; NMDA receptors in LTP
Depression (5-HT deficit hypothesis); OCD; anxiety disorders; SSRIs increase 5-HT availability
Alzheimer's (ACh deficit); myasthenia gravis (receptor antibodies); botulinum toxin (blocks release)
questions.explanation: Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain, and its clinical associations include excitotoxicity (where excessive glutamate causes neuronal death, contributing to stroke damage) and the involvement of NMDA receptors in long-term potentiation (LTP). This is distinct from GABA (the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter associated with anxiety and seizures), serotonin (associated with depression and OCD), and acetylcholine (associated with Alzheimer's disease).

questions.section: Clinical Significance of Basal Ganglia Dysfunction
rows: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra
Bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, postural instability (hypokinetic)
Degeneration of caudate nucleus and putamen (GABAergic neurons)
Chorea (involuntary writhing movements), cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms (hyperkinetic)
Violent flinging movements of contralateral limbs
options: Degeneration of caudate nucleus and putamen (GABAergic neurons)
Loss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra
Degeneration of globus pallidus and thalamic nuclei
questions.explanation: Hemiballismus is caused by a lesion (typically vascular) of the subthalamic nucleus, which results in violent, involuntary flinging movements of the contralateral limbs. This is distinct from Parkinson's disease (substantia nigra) and Huntington's disease (caudate nucleus and putamen), making it a commonly tested differential on the EPPP.

rows: Sustained attention, divided attention, selective attention, processing speed
Easily distracted, difficulty multitasking, cannot follow conversations in groups
Difficulty managing finances, making decisions, following complex instructions
Immediate memory, recent memory, long-term memory recall
Repeating questions, losing items, forgetting appointments and recent events
Expressive language, receptive language, word finding, grammar
Word-finding pauses, circumlocution, using general terms like "thing" or "it"
Getting lost in familiar places, difficulty using tools, trouble with spatial orientation
Emotion recognition, theory of mind, behavioral regulation
Socially inappropriate behavior, insensitivity to social cues, loss of empathy
questions.correct_value: Planning, decision making, working memory, cognitive flexibility, error correction
options: Sustained attention, divided attention, selective attention, processing speed
Planning, decision making, working memory, cognitive flexibility, error correction
Immediate memory, recent memory, long-term memory recall
Emotion recognition, theory of mind, behavioral regulation
questions.explanation: Executive Function is assessed through planning, decision making, working memory, cognitive flexibility, and error correction. This is commonly confused with Complex Attention (which involves sustained/divided/selective attention and processing speed) because working memory and attention are closely related constructs. However, the DSM-5 specifically classifies working memory and cognitive flexibility under Executive Function rather than Complex Attention.

In Signal Detection Theory, when a signal is present but the observer responds 'No' (fails to detect it), the outcome is a Miss, which corresponds to a Type II error. This is distinct from a False Alarm (Type I error), which occurs when the observer says 'Yes' but no signal is present, and from a Correct Rejection, which occurs when the observer correctly says 'No' when no signal is present.

rows: Your old phone number interferes with remembering your new one
Newly learned information interferes with the recall of previously learned information
Learning your new phone number makes it harder to remember your old one
questions.correct_value: Previously learned information interferes with the learning or recall of new information
options: Newly learned information interferes with the recall of previously learned information
Previously learned information interferes with the learning or recall of new information
Old memories are permanently overwritten by new memories due to trace decay
New information fails to encode due to lack of consolidation during sleep
questions.explanation: Proactive interference occurs when previously learned (old) information interferes with the ability to learn or recall new information. The prefix 'pro' means forward, indicating that the old information moves forward in time to disrupt new learning. This is distinct from retroactive interference, where newly learned information disrupts recall of old information.

The parasympathetic division originates from craniosacral regions, specifically cranial nerves (III, VII, IX, X) and sacral spinal segments S2-S4. This is frequently tested on the EPPP and commonly confused with the sympathetic division's thoracolumbar origin (T1-L2).

rows: Blockage of a cerebral artery (thrombus or embolus) cutting off blood supply
Thrombotic (clot forms in situ) or embolic (clot travels from elsewhere); treated with tPA within 4.5 hours
Rupture of a cerebral blood vessel causing bleeding into or around the brain
Intracerebral hemorrhage or subarachnoid hemorrhage; higher mortality; often associated with hypertension or aneurysm
questions.explanation: Ischemic strokes account for approximately 87% of all strokes, making them far more prevalent than hemorrhagic strokes (~13%). This is a commonly tested distinction on the EPPP, as the two types differ significantly in prevalence, mechanism, and treatment approach.

N2 sleep is characterized by theta waves combined with sleep spindles (bursts of 12-14 Hz activity) and K-complexes (sharp negative deflections followed by positive components). These are the hallmark EEG features that distinguish N2 from other sleep stages, and they are frequently tested on the EPPP.

In the Atkinson-Shiffrin model, short-term memory relies primarily on acoustic (phonological) encoding. This is supported by research showing that errors in STM tasks tend to be sound-based (e.g., confusing similar-sounding letters). This is commonly confused with long-term memory, which relies primarily on semantic encoding.

Conduction aphasia is characterized by severely impaired repetition, which is its hallmark deficit. This is because the lesion is in the arcuate fasciculus, the white matter tract connecting Wernicke's and Broca's areas. While comprehension and fluency are largely intact, the disconnection between these two language areas makes repetition disproportionately and severely impaired — distinguishing it from other aphasias where repetition is merely 'impaired.'

rows: Fine motor control of dominant hand
questions.explanation: The right hemisphere is specialized for facial recognition and emotional prosody, which corresponds to the left hemisphere's role in mathematical calculation. Facial recognition and emotional prosody are right-hemisphere functions that reflect its superiority in processing emotional and social cues, and this is a commonly tested lateralization fact on the EPPP.

rows: Different frequencies cause peak vibration at different locations along the basilar membrane (base = high frequency, apex = low frequency)
The basilar membrane vibrates as a whole at the same frequency as the sound wave; firing rate matches frequency
Groups of neurons fire in alternating volleys, with the combined firing rate matching the stimulus frequency
options: Covers the full audible range (~20–20,000 Hz)
questions.explanation: The Volley Principle extends the explanatory range of frequency theory beyond its ~500 Hz limit up to approximately 5,000 Hz by proposing that groups of neurons fire in alternating volleys, allowing the combined neural firing rate to match higher stimulus frequencies than any single neuron could achieve alone.

rows: Voluntary movement, executive function, speech production
Contralateral paralysis, Broca's aphasia, personality changes
Contralateral sensory loss, neglect syndrome, apraxia
Wernicke's aphasia, auditory agnosia, memory impairment
questions.explanation: The primary cortex of the temporal lobe is the auditory cortex, located in Heschl's gyrus. This is a highly testable fact because Heschl's gyrus is frequently confused with other named gyri (e.g., precentral or postcentral gyrus), and the temporal lobe's role in auditory processing and language comprehension (including Wernicke's area) makes this a critical association for the EPPP.

questions.section: Wernicke's Area (Posterior Superior Temporal Gyrus, Typically Left Hemisphere)
questions.explanation: Patients with Wernicke's aphasia are typically unaware of their deficit (anosognosia), producing fluent but meaningless speech without recognizing the errors. This contrasts with Broca's aphasia patients, who are acutely aware of and frustrated by their difficulty producing speech.

rows: Blockage of a cerebral artery (thrombus or embolus)
Rupture of a cerebral blood vessel
Thrombotic (clot forms in situ), embolic (clot travels from elsewhere)
Blood pressure control; surgical evacuation if needed
options: Blood pressure control; surgical evacuation if needed
Mannitol for ICP reduction; coil embolization
questions.explanation: The acute treatment for ischemic stroke is tPA (a thrombolytic agent) administered within a 4.5-hour window from symptom onset, along with mechanical thrombectomy for large vessel occlusions. This is a critical time-sensitive intervention that EPPP candidates must know. The 4.5-hour window is a highly testable detail that distinguishes it from other treatment protocols. Blood pressure control and surgical evacuation are treatments for hemorrhagic stroke, not ischemic stroke.

rows: Anterograde amnesia (H.M.); reduced volume in PTSD
Fear conditioning, emotional processing, memory modulation
Voluntary movement, procedural learning, habit formation
Motor coordination, balance, motor learning, timing
Primary norepinephrine source; arousal and attention
Primary serotonin source; mood and sleep regulation
Implicated in depression and sleep disorders
options: Implicated in depression and sleep disorders
questions.explanation: The locus coeruleus, located in the pons and serving as the brain's primary norepinephrine source, has been identified as 'ground zero' for Alzheimer's disease because it is one of the earliest structures to show tau pathology. This is a highly testable fact because examinees may confuse it with other brainstem nuclei or associate Alzheimer's primarily with the hippocampus.

rows: Loss of consciousness, tonic phase (stiffening), clonic phase (rhythmic jerking), postictal confusion
Most dramatic seizure type; postictal period may last minutes to hours
Brief lapses in consciousness (5-30 seconds), staring, subtle automatisms
Seizure activity in one brain region; consciousness preserved
Symptoms depend on focus location (motor, sensory, autonomic, psychic)
Seizure beginning focally with altered consciousness; automatisms
Most commonly temporal lobe origin; may include deja vu, fear, lip smacking
Continuous seizure activity lasting >5 minutes or repeated seizures without recovery
Medical emergency; can cause brain damage and death; requires IV benzodiazepines
questions.correct_value: Common in children; characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave on EEG; often mistaken for daydreaming
options: Most commonly temporal lobe origin; may include deja vu, fear, lip smacking
Common in children; characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave on EEG; often mistaken for daydreaming
Most dramatic seizure type; postictal period may last minutes to hours
Symptoms depend on focus location (motor, sensory, autonomic, psychic)
questions.explanation: Absence (petit mal) seizures are characterized by a distinctive 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG, are most common in children, and are frequently mistaken for daydreaming due to their brief, subtle presentation. This EEG finding is a highly testable and pathognomonic feature that distinguishes absence seizures from other seizure types.

rows: Early, prominent personality change: disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive/ritualistic behaviors, dietary changes (hyperorality, sweet food preference), executive dysfunction. Memory and visuospatial function relatively preserved early on.
Effortful, halting speech; agrammatism; speech sound errors (apraxia of speech); relatively preserved word comprehension and object knowledge.
questions.correct_value: Progressive loss of word meaning (semantic memory); fluent but empty speech; anomia; surface dyslexia (irregular word reading errors); may lose knowledge of objects and faces.
options: Effortful, halting speech; agrammatism; speech sound errors (apraxia of speech); relatively preserved word comprehension and object knowledge.
Progressive loss of word meaning (semantic memory); fluent but empty speech; anomia; surface dyslexia (irregular word reading errors); may lose knowledge of objects and faces.

Early, prominent personality change: disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive/ritualistic behaviors, dietary changes (hyperorality, sweet food preference), executive dysfunction. Memory and visuospatial function relatively preserved early on.
Gradual onset of word-finding difficulty with preserved grammar; phonemic paraphasias; impaired repetition; relatively preserved single-word comprehension and object knowledge.
questions.explanation: Semantic variant PPA is characterized by progressive loss of semantic memory (word meaning), resulting in fluent but empty speech, anomia, surface dyslexia, and eventual loss of object and face knowledge. This is commonly confused with nonfluent variant PPA, which instead features effortful/halting speech and agrammatism, and with logopenic variant PPA (a related but distinct syndrome associated with Alzheimer pathology), which features word-finding pauses and impaired repetition.

rows: Fear conditioning, emotional processing, memory modulation
Dopamine production for motor control; degenerates in Parkinson's
Motor coordination, balance, motor learning, timing
Primary norepinephrine source; arousal and attention
Primary serotonin source; mood and sleep regulation
questions.correct_value: Sensory relay station (all senses except olfaction)
options: Sensory relay station (all senses except olfaction)
Fear conditioning, emotional processing, memory modulation
questions.explanation: The thalamus serves as the brain's sensory relay station, routing incoming sensory information to the appropriate cortical areas for all senses except olfaction, which projects directly to the cortex. This is a high-yield EPPP fact often confused with the hypothalamus (homeostasis) or the reticular activating system (arousal).

rows: Inability to form new long-term declarative memories after injury
Affects all new memories from injury onward
Inability to retrieve memories formed before injury
Temporary episode of anterograde + retrograde amnesia, resolving within 24 hours
Confusion and memory impairment following TBI
options: Affects all new memories from injury onward
questions.explanation: Retrograde amnesia characteristically exhibits a temporal gradient known as Ribot's Law, in which recently formed memories are more vulnerable to disruption than remote memories. This is because older memories have undergone greater consolidation and are less dependent on hippocampal structures, making them more resistant to loss following injury.

rows: Depression, cognitive slowing, fatigue, apathy, psychomotor retardation; can mimic major depressive disorder
Weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, bradycardia, myxedema
Weight loss, heat intolerance, tremor, tachycardia, exophthalmos (Graves' disease)
questions.correct_value: Anxiety, irritability, emotional lability, insomnia, difficulty concentrating; can mimic generalized anxiety disorder or mania
options: Depression, cognitive slowing, fatigue, apathy, psychomotor retardation; can mimic major depressive disorder
Euphoria, grandiosity, pressured speech, decreased need for sleep; can mimic bipolar I disorder
Anxiety, irritability, emotional lability, insomnia, difficulty concentrating; can mimic generalized anxiety disorder or mania
Paranoia, hallucinations, disorganized thinking, social withdrawal; can mimic schizophreniform disorder
questions.explanation: Hyperthyroidism (elevated T3/T4, suppressed TSH) is classically associated with anxiety, irritability, emotional lability, insomnia, and difficulty concentrating. Its psychiatric presentation can mimic generalized anxiety disorder or mania. This is frequently tested on the EPPP because it is commonly confused with the depressive presentation of hypothyroidism, and distinguishing the psychiatric manifestations of each thyroid condition is clinically essential.

rows: Light sleep, hypnagogic hallucinations, myoclonic jerks
Largest proportion of total sleep; memory consolidation
Vivid dreaming, muscle atonia, rapid eye movements
questions.correct_value: Slow-wave sleep (SWS); deepest sleep; growth hormone release
options: Vivid dreaming, muscle atonia, rapid eye movements
Largest proportion of total sleep; memory consolidation
Slow-wave sleep (SWS); deepest sleep; growth hormone release
Light sleep, hypnagogic hallucinations, myoclonic jerks
questions.explanation: NREM Stage 3 (N3) is characterized by delta waves and is known as slow-wave sleep (SWS). It represents the deepest stage of sleep and is the primary stage during which growth hormone is released from the anterior pituitary. This is commonly confused with REM sleep features or Stage 2's role in memory consolidation.

Dementia (Major Neurocognitive Disorder) has an insidious onset that develops gradually over months to years, in contrast to delirium which has an acute onset over hours to days. This distinction in onset is one of the most critical differentiating features between the two conditions on the EPPP.

Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the white matter tract connecting Wernicke's area to Broca's area. This disconnection specifically impairs repetition while leaving fluency and comprehension relatively intact, which is the hallmark feature distinguishing conduction aphasia from other aphasia syndromes.

rows: X-ray beams rotated around the head; computer reconstruction of cross-sectional images
Fast (minutes), widely available, excellent for bone and acute hemorrhage
Ionizing radiation, lower soft tissue resolution than MRI
Emergency evaluation of acute stroke (rule out hemorrhage), head trauma, skull fractures
Superior soft tissue contrast, no ionizing radiation, multiplanar imaging
Slower, more expensive, contraindicated with certain metal implants and pacemakers, claustrophobia
Detailed brain anatomy, white matter lesions (MS plaques), tumor characterization, hippocampal atrophy
questions.correct_value: Strong magnetic field aligns hydrogen atoms; radiofrequency pulses cause signal emission detected by receiver coils
options: X-ray beams rotated around the head; computer reconstruction of cross-sectional images
Strong magnetic field aligns hydrogen atoms; radiofrequency pulses cause signal emission detected by receiver coils
Injection of radioactive tracer (glucose analog) that accumulates in metabolically active areas; gamma ray detection by ring of detectors
Measurement of blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signal changes reflecting regional cerebral blood flow
questions.explanation: MRI works by using a strong magnetic field to align hydrogen atoms in the body, then applying radiofrequency pulses that cause these atoms to emit signals detected by receiver coils. This mechanism is distinct from CT (which uses X-rays), PET (which uses radioactive tracers), and fMRI (which measures BOLD signal changes, though fMRI is itself based on MRI technology).

questions.correct_value: Moderate at best; creates illusion of learning
options: Moderate at best; creates illusion of learning
questions.explanation: Rereading is a passive re-exposure strategy that produces only moderate retention at best. Critically, it creates an 'illusion of learning' (also called the fluency illusion), where increased familiarity with the material is mistaken for genuine understanding and retention, making students overconfident in their knowledge despite poor actual recall performance.

Moderate traumatic brain injury is characterized by post-traumatic amnesia lasting 1-7 days. This falls between mild TBI (< 24 hours of PTA) and severe TBI (> 7 days of PTA), and is a commonly tested distinction in TBI severity classification.

rows: Drowsiness, light sleep, meditative states; normal in children; may indicate pathology in awake adults
Relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed; prominent over occipital regions; attenuates when eyes open ("alpha blocking")
Active thinking, concentration, anxiety; prominent over frontal regions
Higher cognitive processing, perceptual binding; associated with consciousness
questions.correct_value: Deep sleep (NREM Stage 3); pathological if present during waking in adults (brain damage, encephalopathy)
options: Drowsiness, light sleep, meditative states; normal in children; may indicate pathology in awake adults
Deep sleep (NREM Stage 3); pathological if present during waking in adults (brain damage, encephalopathy)
Relaxed wakefulness with eyes closed; prominent over occipital regions; attenuates when eyes open ("alpha blocking")
Active thinking, concentration, anxiety; prominent over frontal regions
questions.explanation: Delta waves (0.5-4 Hz) are the slowest EEG frequency band and are primarily associated with deep sleep (NREM Stage 3). Their presence during waking states in adults is considered pathological, suggesting brain damage or encephalopathy. This is commonly confused with theta waves, which are associated with drowsiness and light sleep rather than deep sleep.

rows: Discrete attacks (relapses) followed by partial or complete recovery; most common initial form
Initially RRMS, then gradual worsening with or without relapses
Gradual worsening from onset without distinct relapses
questions.explanation: Secondary Progressive MS (SPMS) develops as a conversion from Relapsing-Remitting MS, with approximately 50% of RRMS patients transitioning to SPMS within 10-15 years. This is a commonly tested statistic that distinguishes SPMS from the other subtypes, which have different prevalence figures (~85% for RRMS at onset and ~10-15% for PPMS).

rows: Temporal cortex (independent of hippocampus for well-established knowledge)
Faster word recognition after prior exposure
questions.explanation: Classical conditioning involves the cerebellum for motor-based conditioned responses such as the eyeblink reflex, and the amygdala for fear-based conditioned emotional responses. This is distinct from procedural memory (basal ganglia, cerebellum, motor cortex) and priming (neocortex), which rely on different neural substrates despite all being implicit memory systems.

Lazarus's Cognitive Appraisal theory argues that a cognitive appraisal of a situation must occur before an emotional response can be generated. This contrasts directly with Zajonc's Affective Primacy hypothesis, which holds that emotion can precede cognition, and with Schachter and Singer's Two-Factor theory, which emphasizes the combination of physiological arousal and a cognitive label.

questions.section: Apraxia, Agnosia & Other Higher Cortical Deficits
rows: Failure to attend to contralateral space
questions.explanation: Prosopagnosia — the inability to recognize familiar faces — is associated with damage to the fusiform face area bilaterally. This is distinct from visual agnosia (bilateral occipitotemporal), anosognosia and hemispatial neglect (right parietal lobe), and ideomotor apraxia (left parietal lobe). The fusiform face area is a specialized region critical for face perception, making it a high-yield association for the EPPP.

rows: The process of transforming information into a form that can be stored in memory
Grouping individual items into larger meaningful units to increase STM capacity
Baddeley's multicomponent system for actively maintaining and manipulating information
Memory for personally experienced events (part of declarative memory)
Memory for general knowledge and facts (part of declarative memory)
Memory for skills and habits (part of nondeclarative memory)
New learning disrupts recall of old learning
Inability to form new memories after onset of amnesia
Inability to recall memories formed before onset of amnesia
Fabrication of memories without intent to deceive, seen in Korsakoff's syndrome
Post-event information alters memory for the original event (Loftus)
questions.correct_value: Old learning disrupts recall of new learning
options: New learning disrupts recall of old learning
Old learning disrupts recall of new learning
Post-event information alters memory for the original event (Loftus)
Inability to form new memories after onset of amnesia
questions.explanation: Proactive interference occurs when previously learned (old) information interferes with the ability to recall newly learned information. This is commonly confused with retroactive interference, where new learning disrupts recall of old learning. The key distinction is the direction of interference: 'proactive' means old memories act forward to disrupt new ones.

rows: Physiological arousal precedes and produces emotional experience
Arousal and emotional experience occur simultaneously via thalamic relay
Emotion requires arousal plus cognitive labeling (Schachter-Singer)
Primary glucocorticoid stress hormone from adrenal cortex
Cumulative physiological wear from chronic stress (McEwen)
Study of interactions among psychological, neural, and immune systems
Fight-or-flight division of the autonomic nervous system
Rest-and-digest division of the autonomic nervous system
questions.correct_value: Alarm, resistance, exhaustion stages of prolonged stress (Selye)
options: Cumulative physiological wear from chronic stress (McEwen)
Alarm, resistance, exhaustion stages of prolonged stress (Selye)
Study of interactions among psychological, neural, and immune systems
questions.explanation: Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) describes three sequential stages of the body's response to prolonged stress: alarm (initial fight-or-flight activation), resistance (sustained coping efforts), and exhaustion (depletion of resources). This is commonly confused with allostatic load, which refers to cumulative wear from chronic stress but does not describe discrete stages.

rows: Topographic map of body representation on the primary motor cortex
Nonfluent, effortful speech with preserved comprehension (left inferior frontal)
Fluent but meaningless speech with impaired comprehension (left posterior temporal)
Failure to attend to contralateral space, typically left neglect from right parietal damage
Inability to recognize faces despite intact visual acuity
Functional specialization of the cerebral hemispheres
Major commissure connecting left and right hemispheres
"What" pathway for object recognition (occipital to temporal)
"Where/how" pathway for spatial processing (occipital to parietal)
questions.correct_value: Fluent speech, intact comprehension, impaired repetition (arcuate fasciculus)
options: Nonfluent, effortful speech with preserved comprehension (left inferior frontal)
Fluent but meaningless speech with impaired comprehension (left posterior temporal)
Fluent speech, intact comprehension, impaired repetition (arcuate fasciculus)
Failure to attend to contralateral space, typically left neglect from right parietal damage
questions.explanation: Conduction aphasia is characterized by fluent speech and intact comprehension, but the hallmark deficit is impaired repetition due to damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the white matter tract connecting Wernicke's area to Broca's area. This distinguishes it from Broca's aphasia (nonfluent speech) and Wernicke's aphasia (impaired comprehension), which are common distractors on the EPPP.

rows: Brief 12-14 Hz EEG bursts in N2 sleep; involved in memory consolidation
Slow (0.5-4 Hz), high-amplitude waves characterizing N3/slow-wave sleep
Skeletal muscle paralysis during REM sleep preventing dream enactment
Suprachiasmatic nucleus; master circadian clock in the anterior hypothalamus
Pineal hormone promoting sleep, released in response to darkness
Homeostatic sleep drive that builds during waking (Borbely)
Circadian alerting signal from the SCN (Borbely)
Sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotion; diagnostic for narcolepsy
Biological marker of major depressive disorder
questions.correct_value: Hypothalamic neuropeptide promoting wakefulness; deficient in narcolepsy
options: Pineal hormone promoting sleep, released in response to darkness
Hypothalamic neuropeptide promoting wakefulness; deficient in narcolepsy
Sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotion; diagnostic for narcolepsy
Homeostatic sleep drive that builds during waking (Borbely)
questions.explanation: Hypocretin (also called orexin) is a hypothalamic neuropeptide that promotes wakefulness, and its deficiency is the key pathological mechanism underlying narcolepsy (particularly Type 1 narcolepsy with cataplexy). This is easily confused with cataplexy (a symptom of narcolepsy rather than its cause) or melatonin (which is a pineal hormone involved in sleep promotion, not wakefulness).

rows: Generalized seizure with rigidity (tonic) then rhythmic jerking (clonic)
Slowness of movement; cardinal feature of Parkinson's disease
Dopamine precursor used to treat Parkinson's disease
Involuntary writhing movements; hallmark of Huntington's disease
Loss of myelin sheath; central pathology of multiple sclerosis
Stroke caused by arterial blockage (87% of strokes)
Stroke caused by blood vessel rupture
Brain injury at impact site and opposite side, respectively
Fluent speech, intact comprehension, severely impaired repetition
questions.correct_value: Brief staring episodes with 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG; common in children
options: Generalized seizure with rigidity (tonic) then rhythmic jerking (clonic)
Brief staring episodes with 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG; common in children
Involuntary writhing movements; hallmark of Huntington's disease
Fluent speech, intact comprehension, severely impaired repetition
questions.explanation: Absence seizures are characterized by brief staring episodes (formerly called 'petit mal' seizures), a distinctive 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG, and are most common in children. This is highly testable because the specific EEG frequency (3 Hz) is a classic board-style detail that distinguishes absence seizures from other seizure types.
